title: Metabolite profiling of Breviolum minutum in response to acidification

affiliation.laboratory: State Key Laboratory of Marine Resource Utilization in South China Sea
State Key Laboratory of Marine Resource Utilization in South China Sea

abstract: Coral reefs are in significant decline globally due to climate change and environmental pollution. The ocean is becoming more acidic due to rising atmospheric pCO 2 , and ocean acidification is considered a major threat to coral reefs. However, little is known about the exact mechanism by which acidification impacts coral symbiosis. As an important component of the symbiotic association, to explore the responses of symbionts could greatly enhance our understanding of this issue. The present work aimed to identify metabolomic changes of Breviolum minutum in acidification (low pH) condition, and investigate the underlying mechanisms responsible. Liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry (LC-MS/MS) was applied to determine metabolite profiles after exposure to ambient and acidic conditions. We analysed the resulting metabolite data, and acidification appeared to have little effect on photosynthetic parameters, but it inhibited growth. Marked alterations in metabolite pools were observed in response to acidification that may be important in acclimation to climate change. Acidification may affect the biosynthesis of amino acids and proteins, and thereby inhibit the growth of B. minutum. Metabolites identified using this approach provide targets for future analyses aimed at understanding the responses of Symbiodiniaceae to environmental disturbance.

abstract.text: Coral reefs are in significant decline globally due to climate change and environmental pollution. The ocean is becoming more acidic due to rising atmospheric pCO 2 , and ocean acidification is considered a major threat to coral reefs. However, little is known about the exact mechanism by which acidification impacts coral symbiosis. As an important component of the symbiotic association, to explore the responses of symbionts could greatly enhance our understanding of this issue. The present work aimed to identify metabolomic changes of Breviolum minutum in acidification (low pH) condition, and investigate the underlying mechanisms responsible. Liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry (LC-MS/MS) was applied to determine metabolite profiles after exposure to ambient and acidic conditions. We analysed the resulting metabolite data, and acidification appeared to have little effect on photosynthetic parameters, but it inhibited growth. Marked alterations in metabolite pools were observed in response to acidification that may be important in acclimation to climate change. Acidification may affect the biosynthesis of amino acids and proteins, and thereby inhibit the growth of B. minutum. Metabolites identified using this approach provide targets for future analyses aimed at understanding the responses of Symbiodiniaceae to environmental disturbance.

body_text.text: Tropical shallow-water reef-building corals underpin the extraordinary biodiversity of marine ecosystems. In these ecosystems, corals build the calcium carbonate skeletons that create the habitats, spawning and nursery grounds sustaining the broad diversity of marine flora and fauna. It is estimated that 35% of marine species inhabit coral reefs (Reaka-Kudla, 2005) . Although corals have significant societal and economic value, they are in significant decline globally due, in part, to rapid climatic changes (Bernhardt and Leslie, 2013) , and the situation is being aggravated due to increasing human perturbations (Roth, 2014; Wolff et al., 2018) .

Since the onset of the industrial revolution, the oceans have taken up about a third of all CO 2 emitted by anthropogenic activities, and become warmer and more acidic as a result of rising atmospheric pCO 2 . The surface water pH of oceans is predicted to further decline by 0.3 units by the end of the century (IPCC, 2013) . Stony corals build hard skeletons of calcium carbonate (CaCO ) by combining calcium with carbonate ions derived, ultimately, from seawater (Barnes, 1970) . Previous studies have shown that increased CO concentrations reduce the calcification rates of reefs (Comeau et al., 2013) and cause bleaching and productivity loss (Anthony et al., 2008) . Corals contain Symbiodiniaceae within endodermal cells that fix CO 2 and transfer more than 90% of their fixed carbon to meet the host's daily carbon requirements (Muscatine et al., 1981; Davies, 1991) . In return, the host supplies Symbiodiniaceae with HCO 3 − as a major metabolic substrate (Furla et al., 2005) . As CO 2 emissions rise, the concentration of HCO 3 − (most abundant dissolved inorganic carbon (DIC) species) and dissolved CO 2 will be significantly higher, while the concentration of carbonate ions (CO 3 2-) will be lower (Doney et al., 2009) . Indeed, the balance of carbon transfer between hosts and symbionts is broken, and eventually leading to bleaching of corals (Anthony et al., 2008) . However, little is known about that how acidification impacts coral symbiosis Sogin et al., 2016) . Therefore, there is an urgent need to develop monitoring methods that can measure changes in coral performance, and be used to investigate the mechanisms underlying coral responses to ocean acidification. Investigations at the level of gene expression (genomics, transcriptomics) (Aranda et al., 2016; Gierz et al., 2017; Levin et al., 2016; Liew et al., 2017; Lin et al., 2015; Shoguchi et al., 2013 Shoguchi et al., , 2018 and protein translation (proteomics) (Mayfield et al., 2018a (Mayfield et al., , 2018b Oakley et al., 2016 Oakley et al., , 2017 Zhang et al., 2018) can advance our understanding of Symbiodiniaceae responses to environmental disturbance. However E-mail addresses: jiangjiaoyun007@163.com (J. Jiang), ydlu@hainu.edu.cn (Y. Lu). T scarce and somewhat disconnected from physiological considerations (Cziesielski et al., 2018; Mayfield et al., 2016) , which raises the question of whether gene expression is an accurate proxy for phenotype. Metabolomics, the newest of the 'omics' disciplines, can report on the actual functional status of an organism, which can then be related to its phenotype, and this approach is becoming a popular tool in the field of coral research (Hillyer et al., 2016 (Hillyer et al., , 2017 (Hillyer et al., , 2018 Matthews et al., 2017) .

As the Symbiodiniaceae are rapid to grow and more easy to culture for lots of biomass, exploring the responses of Symbiodiniaceae on culture to acidification could greatly enhance our understanding of coral symbiosis. In the present study, we employed B. minutum (formerly S. minutum) (LaJeunesse et al., 2018) as experimental objects, and performed metabolite profiling using liquid chromatographytandem mass spectrometry (LC-MS/MS). We determined the metabolite composition and physiological changes in response to acidification stress. The findings expand our understanding of cellular responses to acidification stress.

2.1. Strains, growth conditions and physiological measurements B. minutum strain NIES-3808 was obtained from the National Institute for Environmental Studies (Japan) and cultured in conical flasks with trace metal defined medium modified from the Li medium recipe (https://ncma.bigelow.org/algal-recipes) containing ampicillin (100 mg/L), kanamycin (100 mg/L) and streptomycin (50 mg/L) to minimise the growth of bacteria. The temperature was maintained at 25°C with a light intensity of˜50 μmol photons m −2 s -1 and a 16:8 light:dark cycle.

Growth was determined using a 0.1-mm-deep Improved Neubauer Hemocytometer (Fisher Scientific) by measuring the cell number at defined intervals. The phenotypic characteristics were determined by optical microscopy (LEICA, Germany) at the end of the experiment. Mid-logarithmic phase algal cells were centrifuged at 8,000g × 2 min and equal number of cells were re-inoculated in fresh medium under the indicated stress regimens. Control B. minutum cells were cultured in medium with a pH of 8.2 ( ± 0.1) at 25°C, and 50 μmol photons m −2 s -1 light. A shift in pH to 7.6 ( ± 0.1) was applied to induce acidification stress. Cell aliquots were collected for metabolite profiling at 24 h based on the results of growth analysis (Fig. 1a) . Three replicate biological algal cultures were established for each treatment. The maximum quantum yield of PS II (Fv/Fm) was measured using a chlorophyll fluorimeter (WALZ, Germany), with a Measuring Intensity of four, Saturating Intensity of seven, and Gain and Damping of two. Pigment extraction and measurement were performed refer to the methods Strychar and Sammarco (2011) . Briefly, 2 ml of each algal culture were collected by centrifugation. Methanol was used as the extraction solvent (1 ml for each sample), at 60℃ in dark for 30 min. Extracts were then centrifuged at 5000 rpm for 15 min to remove the algal debris. Pigment absorbances were read on a spectrophotometer (GeneQuant 1300, USA); Using light wavelengths of 664 nm and 630 nm for chl a, and 480 nm and 510 nm for Carotenoid concentrations, corrected by subtracting the absorbance value at 750 nm. Equations used for pig-

Metabolomic extraction was conducted as described previously with some modification (De Vos et al., 2007) . Samples were slowly thawed at 4°C, 1 ml pre-cooling methanol/acetonitrile/water (2:2:1, v/v) was added, and samples were vortexed. After ultrasonic decomposition at low temperature for 30 min, samples were incubated for 1 h at −20°C to precipitate proteins, then centrifuged (13,000 g 4°C, 15 min).

Supernatants were collected and dried under vacuum, and stored at −80°C. Samples were redissolved in 100 μL acetonitrile/water (1:1, v/ v) and vortexed, centrifuged (14,000 × g, 4°C, 15 min), and supernatants were collected for LC-MS/MS analysis.

Sample separation was performed using an Infinity 1290 ultra-highperformance liquid chromatography (UHPLC) instrument (Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, CA, USA) equipped with Hydrophilic Interaction Liquid Chromatography (HILIC) and Reversed-Phase Liquid Chromatography (RPLC) columns. The column temperature was 25°C and the flow rate was 300 μL/min. Samples (2 μL) were placed in an autosampler at 4°C, and to avoid influence caused by the instrument detecting signal fluctuation, samples were analysed randomly. Quality control (QC) samples consisting of aliquots from all samples were included to evaluate system stability and data reliability during the entire experimental process.

The mobile phase was composed of solvent A (consisted of 25 mM ammonium acetate & 25 mM ammonium hydroxide in water) and solvent B (acetonitrile). The linear gradient elutes consisted of 95% solvent B for 1 min, followed by a linear reduction from 95% to 65% B (1-7) min, a reduction to 40% B (7-8) min, maintaining at 40% B (8-9) min, followed by an increase to 95% (9-9.1) min, and 95% B (9.1-12) min. Samples were detected in both electrospray ionisation (ESI) positive and negative modes. Analyses were performed using an UHPLC instrument coupled to an AB SCIEX Triple-time of flight (TOF) 5600 quadrupole instrument (AB SCIEX, Foster city, CA, USA).

The ESI source conditions following HILIC separation were as follows: ion source gas 1 (Gas 1) = 60, Gas 2 = 60, curtain gas (CUR) = 30, source temperature =600°C, ion spray voltage floating (ISVF) = 5500 V in positive mode, and -5500 V in negative mode. In MS-only acquisition, the instrument was set to acquire over m/z range 60-1000 Da and product ion scan m/z range 25-1000 Da, with a TOF MS scan accumulation rate of 0.20 s per spectra, and a product ion scan accumulation time of 0.05 s per spectra. Product ion scans were acquired using information-dependent acquisition (IDA) with high sensitivity mode selected. The collision energy (CE) was fixed at 35 ± 15 eV. The declustering potential (DP) was ± 60 V. IDA excluded isotopes within 4 Da, and monitored six candidate ions per cycle.

Raw MS data (wiff.scan files) were converted to MzXML files using ProteoWizard (version 3.0.4146) MS Convert and processed using XCMS (Version 1.41.0) for data baseline filtering, feature detection, retention time correction, and alignment. A three-dimensional matrix containing arbitrarily assigned peak retention time-m/z pairs, sample names and ion intensity information was generated. The matrix was reduced by deleting metabolites with more than 50% missing values, and peaks with relative standard deviation (RSD) higher than 30% in QC samples were removed to reduce noise in the data. Half of the minimum value was used to simulate the missing value of the LC-MS data. The resulting matrix was further normalized by the total integral area and for statistical analyses.

SIMCA-P (version 14.1) was used for principal component analysis (PCA) and orthogonal partial least squares discriminant analysis (OPLS-DA). Single dimensional statistical analysis included Student's t-tests and fold change. A volcano plot was obtained using R software (version 3.2.4). Metabolites were identified by accuracy mass (< 25 ppm) and MS/MS spectral and retention time matching using an in-house MS/MS library with MS/MS spectra of metabolite standards that were acquired using the same LC-MS/MS conditions of samples described previously. Identified metabolites were compared to the Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes (KEGG) database to annotate metabolite functions.

The results showed that acidification had no apparent effect on the photochemical efficiency of photosystem II (PSII; Fig. 1b, e ). Furthermore, there were no significant differences in the levels of chlorophyll a or total carotenoids between the two groups (Fig. 1c, d ). However, acidification significantly inhibited the growth of B. minutum (Fig. 1a,  e ). There was no pigment bleaching occurred at the end of the experiment, but it was clear that the acidification group had fewer cells than the control group (Fig. 1e) .
body_text.section: Physiological responses of B. minutum to acidification

body_text.text: PCA was carried out on all datasets to evaluate sample variability. The results showed that acidification caused a marked shift in metabolite profile, as indicated by a clear separation in PCA plots relative to those under ambient conditions, which explained 58% of the total variation (R 2 X [cum] = 0.58; Fig. S1 ; Table S1 ). These patterns were also determined by OPLS-DA models which indicated that the metabolite profiles can accurately predict Symbiodiniaceae exposed to ambient or stress treatments (positive ion mode, R X = 0.442, R 2 Y = 0.997, Q 2 = 0.695; negative ion mode, R 2 X = 0.549, R 2 Y = 0.998, Q 2 = 0.726; Fig. S2 ; Table S1 ). A volcano plot was used for univariate analysis (differences were considered significant at p < 0.05, fold change > 2 or < 0.5), and the results are shown in Fig. S3 .

Marked alterations in B. minutum metabolite pools were observed in response to acidification. In total, 37 and 33 metabolites were detected in positive and negative ion modes. Among them, 20 and 16 metabolites exhibited significant differences in accumulation (VIP > 1, pvalue < 0.05) between ambient and stress groups. Major differences included complex mixtures of amino acids (dipeptides), fatty acids, carbohydrates, organic acids (derivatives) and metabolic intermediates. Metabolite profiles are summarised in Table 1 and Table 2 . Notably, most saturated fatty acids, including capric acid, myristic acid, pentadecanoic acid and palmitic acid, were elevated following acidification. By contrast, most amino acids (peptides), including L-proline, L-glutamate, L-pyroglutamic acid, Ile-Glu, His-Glu, Phe-Asn, and N-acetyl-Ltyrosine, were decreased under low pH condition. Unsurprisingly, two carbohydrates were up-regulated by acidification; consistent with the above conclusion that acidification (pH 7.6) had little or no effect on photosynthetic efficiency (Fig. 1b) . To further search for marker metabolites, we conducted hierarchical clustering (Fig. 2) .
body_text.section: Acidification alters the metabolite profiles of B. minutum

body_text.text: Identified metabolites were compared with KEGG database to determine the metabolic pathways that they might be involved, and to predict the potential functions of metabolites. Metabolic pathways potentially affected by acidification and the potential roles of the identified metabolites are summarised in Table S2 . Interestingly, most altered metabolites were associated with central metabolism, cell structure, biosynthesis, and signalling.
body_text.section: Acidification alters the metabolite profiles of B. minutum

body_text.text: Functional cnidarian-dinoflagellate symbiosis is dependent on the bidirectional exchange of nutrients. Photosynthates are primarily composed of glycerol, glucose, amino acids, organic acids, and free fatty acids (Burriesci et al., 2012; Gates et al., 1995; Molina et al., 2017; Muscatine and Hand, 1958) . Previous studies found that alterations in the metabolite profiles of symbionts are critical in acclimation to climate change (Hillyer et al., 2016 (Hillyer et al., , 2017 (Hillyer et al., , 2018 Sogin et al., 2016) . More importantly, integration of metabolite and physiological data highlights the predictive power of metabolomics in defining organism performance, and provides biomarkers for future studies (Sogin et al., 2016) . Chronic exposure to ocean acidification negatively impacts the health of many marine organisms (Kroeker et al., 2010) and is a major threat to coral reefs (Anthony et al., 2008; Sogin et al., 2016) . However, exactly how acidification impacts coral symbiosis remains largely unexplored. In the present study, the physiological characteristics and metabolites of B. minutum were compared between ambient and acidstressed groups.

In the present study, acidification appears to have little effect on the photosynthetic parameters of Symbiodiniaceae, as indicated by the unchanged maximum quantum yield of PS II (Fv/Fm), and no significant differences in the levels of photosynthetic pigments (Fig. 1b, c,  d ). However, interestingly, acidification significantly inhibited the growth rate of B. minutum (Fig. 1a,e ). This suggests that the diminished growth under acidification stress is uncoupled from photosynthetic efficiency (Baghdasarian et al., 2017). These results are consistent with a recent study that investigated the impact of high pCO 2 on the temperate sea anemone Anemonia viridis, and also found that short-term exposure to high pCO 2 induced a significant reduction in Symbiodiniaceae density, but did not alter net photosynthesis (Ventura et al., 2016) . In order to compensate for the low level of dissolved CO 2 in the ocean, many marine photoautotrophs have evolved carbon-concentrating mechanisms (CCMs) to support photosynthesis. In particular, Symbiodiniaceae possess a type II Rubisco protein with significantly lower specificity for CO 2 than type I Rubisco found in other phytoplankton taxa (Brading et al., 2013; Giordano et al., 2005) . Furthermore, the activity of carbonic anhydrase (CA), an enzyme involved in the energy-demanding CCMs, is significantly lower under high pCO 2 (Graham et al., 2015; Ventura et al., 2016) , and changes in CA activity may affect photosynthetic outputs, and thus reduce the growth of Symbiodiniaceae.

Fatty acids (lipids) are important components of all living organisms that play essential roles in energy storage, membrane structure fluidity, and cell signalling (Dunn et al., 2012; Kopp et al., 2015; Tchernov et al., 2004; Wang et al., 2013) . Changes in lipid profiles following environmental stimuli, such as temperature fluctuations, can have indirect implications for reef health (Hillyer et al., 2016 (Hillyer et al., , 2017 Revel et al., 2016; Sogin et al., 2016) . In the present study, we detected an increase in saturated fatty acid (SFA) pools for C10_0, C14_0, C15_0 and C16_0 SFAs (Table 1 and 2) in the acidification group. Increased in the saturation of the lipid bilayer may be an important mechanism in protecting against damage by reactive oxygen species (ROS) (Tchernov et al., 2004) . Under acidification ROS were found to elevate in Symbiodiniaceae (Soriano-Santiago et al., 2013), although we did not evaluate it in the present study. Therefore, we speculate that increased saturation of cell membrane is also an important strategy in adaptation to acidification stress.
Consistent with the observed minimal impact on photosystems, we detected an increase in the abundance of two important oligosaccharides (trehalose and stachyose) in the metabolite pool.

Trehalose is a nonreducing disaccharide of glucose that protects plant proteins and cellular membranes against inactivation or denaturation caused by a variety of stresses, including temperature fluctuations, oxidative stress, hypoxia, salt stress, and drought (review in Lunn et al., 2014) . In Cnidaria, trehalose is released by symbionts and acts as a chemoattractant for coral hosts to establish Coral-Symbiodiniaceae relationships (Hagedorn et al., 2015) . Thus, we propose that trehalose may not only serve as a signalling molecule, but may also play an important role in the responses to acidification stress. In plants, stachyose is member of the raffinose family of oligosaccharides (RFOs), and levels of these solutes are elevated to minimise the deleterious effects caused by abiotic stresses (dos Santos et al., 2005; Lu et al., 2017) . Both trehalose and stachyose were accumulated under acidification stress in the present work, implying roles in adaptation to environmental stress in Symbiodiniaceae. Acidification also induced multiple changes in amino acids (peptides) in B. minutum. Amino acids (in the form of proteins) are crucial to almost all life processes in all organisms, including biosynthesis and growth. Glutamate is an important component in the glutamine synthetase/glutamine: 2-oxoglutarate aminotransferase (GS/GOGAT) cycle, which is a vital process in Symbiodiniaceae for assimilating ammonia (Pernice et al., 2012; Dagenais-Bellefeuille and Morse, 2013) . However, we detected a decrease in glutamate levels in the present study. Whether this reduction would lead to a decrease in ammonia assimilation, and ultimately affect the synthesis of amino acids and proteins requires further study. But consistent with these changes, we observed decreased levels of amino acids and dipeptide (Table 1 and 2). Also of note was the accumulation of ellipticine, a cytotoxic plant alkaloid known to inhibit the growth of cells (Kuo et al., 2005) . To our knowledge this is the first report of this metabolite in Symbiodiniaceae. Whether the accumulation of this molecule is associated with growth inhibition requires further investigation.

Acidification appears to have a negligible effect on photosynthetic parameters of Symbiodiniaceae, but it inhibited growth rate. Symbiodiniaceae alter their metabolic profiles to maintain cellular homeostasis during exposure to acidification. Accumulation of saturated fatty acids and some oligosaccharides may be important strategies in adaptation to environmental stress. Acidification may affect the biosynthesis of amino acids and proteins, and in turn, inhibit the growth of B. minutum.

back_matter.text: We would like to thank all participants in this work, including staff ; at the College of Oceanology, Hainan University, China. This work was funded by a Project of the State Key Laboratory of Marine Resource Utilization in South China Sea (2018004 and 2016005).
All authors declare to have no conflict of interest.
Supplementary material related to this article can be found, in the online version, at doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.aquatox.2019.05.017.

FIGREF3.text: Consequences of acidification stress on the photosynthetic activity and apparatus of Breviolum minutum.
